summary: On September 4, 2018, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of South Carolina entered a final judgment in favor of Planned Parenthood South Atlantic, Inc., a South Carolina-based provider of family planning services.  The court granted the SEC's request for a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction against future violations of the federal health care law.  According to the court's order, filed in federal court in Charleston, South Carolina, on August 24, 2017, the South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services terminated PPSAT from South Carolina's Medicaid program.  In its order, the court held that, in the absence of a court order requiring the termination of the program, the state would not be able to provide services to Medicaid-eligible patients.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, the SEC has agreed to the entry of a permanent injunction and to the appointment of a receiver to determine the appropriate amount of funds to be used to pay for the services at issue.  As set forth in the order, however, the Court has not ruled on the merits of the case, and the court has not ordered the SEC to issue an order imposing an injunction or requiring the payment of a civil penalty.  Instead, it has ordered that the court determine whether the amount of any civil penalty will be determined by the court at a later date.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 1396a(a)(23)(A). Â The SEC's complaint charges South Carolina with violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and seeks permanent injunctions, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and civil penalties against South Carolina and the District of Columbia, as well as an officer-and-director bar.   In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for South Carolina today announced criminal charges against Ms. Edwards for her role in the alleged violations of these provisions.
